Sometimes monitoring volcanos brings you to new heights. Volcanologist Melanie Kelman studies Canadian volcanoes (in BC/YT) and prepares to deal with volcanic unrest.  Really cool! – DK

Forests are a dominant feature of Canada’s landscape and are central to its economy. Forests enrich the lives of all Canadians, offer a place of sanctuary and recreation and are fundamental to the cultural and spiritual values of Indigenous peoples. Forests provide habitat for wildlife, moderate climate and filter air and water. 
On International Day of Forests, March 21, take a moment to Celebrate Canada’s forests. 
#IntForestDay #CDNForests #Wildlife #Forest

Happy International Day of Forests! 
The health and well-being of our nation’s forests matters. 
Canada is proud of its world-recognized forest management practices. The Government of Canada is committed to the sustainable management of its forests so as to maintain their environmental, social and economic values and benefits over time. 
#IntForestDay #CDNForests #Forest

On July 19, 2017, Victoria Tschirhart will be taking over our Instagram account to show us what it’s like to be a geophysicist doing summer fieldwork. She will be showing us everything from what her team is working on to how scientists travel while in remote locations. Stay tuned!

#Fieldwork #SummerFieldwork #NRCanSci #GeoScience #STEMGirls

Climate change is one of the biggest challenges that Canada will face in the next 150 years. Where do we begin? When it comes to defining Canada’s energy future, you can start by telling us your ideas at #GenEnergy http://www.generationenergy.ca.Be a  part of setting the energy course for the next generation of Canadians!

DYK Canada is a world leader in carbon capture and storage? This clean energy technology captures emissions of carbon dioxide from large point sources and safely stores them underground. This is just one of the many ways Canada will meet its GHG emission reduction goals. Do you think CCS is an important way to combat climate change in Canada’s energy future? Tell us what you think at #GenEnergy http://www.generationenergy.ca

Good evening, Instagram! My name is Vicki Tschirhart, and I’m a geophysicist with the Geological Survey of Canada.

Tomorrow, I’m taking over the NRCan Instagram account to give you a glimpse into a day in the life of a geoscientist in the field. Stay tuned!

#Fieldwork #SummerFieldwork #NRCanSci #GeoScience #STEMGirls #wcw #WomenInScience

Hi everyone, and welcome to my summer home! 
It’s geophysicist Vicki Tschirhart here! 
My field site is located in the Patterson Lake corridor, southwestern Athabasca Basin, a region known for its uranium deposits. 
Our multidisciplinary field party includes geochemists, geochronologists, geophysicists and geologists, experts who have the collective goal of understanding how and why these deposits formed. 
#Fieldwork #SummerFieldwork #NRCanSci #GeoScience #Exploration #cribs #homesweethome

When we’re out in the field, we have to get up early. There’s always quite a bit of work to do in the morning, and we need to make sure to eat a big, healthy breakfast to get us through the day! 
#Fieldwork #SummerFieldwork #NRCanSci #GeoScience #Exploration
#protein #FitGoals #work

Today, we will be hiking through the bush to get some drill cores — samples of a natural material previously removed using a cylinder drill. 
While at the core storage area, we take samples and measurements from the drill core to get information about the subsurface. 
Sometimes the drill core is  only accessible by overgrown roads, so it can be quite the journey tracking it down! 
#Fieldwork #SummerFieldwork #Hiking #NRCanSci

When we get to the location, it’s straight to work — everyone has their targets. Each one of us seeks to collect data to solve the research questions we formulated before leaving for the field. 
#work #NRCanSci #Exploration #Fieldwork #uranium

Meet Jeremy! 
My colleague Jeremy Powell is interested in the low-temperature history of southern Athabasca. He’s combing the drill core for fractures and faults, using many different techniques to understand when these structures were active. 
Dating the movement of these structures and the timing of hydrothermal fluids that circulated through them will help us learn how and when these uranium deposits formed.

#Faults #geochron #RockClock #NotMyFault #fieldwork

Kathryn Bethune is a Professor of Geology at the University of Regina. She and her Ph.D. student, Dillon Johnstone, are investigating the regional setting and related structural controls of uranium deposits in the area. 
The primary aim is to create a fuller 2-D and 3-D picture of the major structural features and their relationship to the uranium deposits, as well as getting a fuller understanding of the sequence and timing of structures. 
#WomenInScience #Geology #uranium #Canada

Meet Eric Potter, a fellow research scientist at the GSC. Eric studies how and why these uranium deposits formed. 
For this project, Eric is looking for ancient chemical fingerprints of fluids that formed these deposits. This research is attempting to create a way of identifying faults that channeled the uranium-bearing fluids to the site of the deposit and addressing questions on how the deposits form. 
#fieldwork #uranium #exploration

This is Charlene, everyone’s favourite summer student! 
Charlene is starting an M.Sc. degree in geology this fall, so this expedition will give her some great hands-on experience in remote settings while learning more about economic geology. 
Charlene will be taking detailed measurements on drill core samples, assisting with digital data management, helping manage the camp and contributing ideas to the deposit models. 
#STEMGirls #GeoScience #wcw #WomenInScience

Welcome to “Come dine with me Athabasca,” where Canada’s best and brightest government scientists battle it out to become ultimate camp chef! 
Because we are in a smaller camp, we cook our own food and each member is responsible for at least one communal dinner. This can often lead to some friendly competition as to who’s the best cook. 
#ItsDefinitelyVicki #ComeDineWithMe #CampMeals #Fieldwork

We may be done in the field for the day, but we need to go over the data collected, discuss our findings and plan our targets for tomorrow. Fieldwork often involves very long work days — but it’s worth it for the science. 
#ItsWorthItForTheExercise #AndNature #Fieldwork

Well, thanks for joining us today! We hope you enjoyed learning a bit about the fieldwork we do during the summer! 
Until next time. 
#ByeForNow #Fieldwork
Scrum VS  Swarm: #NRCanSci researchers deliver #SpruceBudworm moth migration media briefing near #Rimouski, Quebec. #Fieldwork
Gotcha! #NRCanSci technician Jean-Michel Béland takes down a #SpruceBudworm trap in #Rimouski to study their outbreaks

“What will Canada’s energy picture look like in the year 2040?” Looking beyond their current work and expertise, participants of the Generation Energy roundtable at Dalhousie University were asked for their vision of Canada’s future energy mix. 
A diverse group — students, academics, Indigenous representatives, energy consultants, members of civil society — they had plenty of insights ready for Natural Resources Canada’s Minister, Jim Carr. 
Dal graduate Samantha Peverell provided her thoughts: “GenEnergy isn’t just about generating energy — it’s about saving energy, too.”

An insectiphobe’s worst nightmare! 
But studying #SpruceBudworm dispersals in Eastern Canada doesn’t bug NRCan scientist Emily Owens. 
#NRCanSci #BugsAreCool #Bugs #CitizenScience #BudwormTrackers

What will it take to fight #ClimateChange? 
A team of the best clean energy “nerds” in Canada! One self-proclaimed “GHG nerd” is Anamika, who was profiled as part of the #GenEnergy initiative. 
Anamika works with Cenovus Energy to find ways to produce oil efficiently while reducing the impact of climate change. “We live in a time where the world wants answers from energy sources and [wants to] transition towards a clean energy future. And as an industry, if we are to be sustainable, it is our responsibility to be part of that clean energy future,” Anamika said. 
Curious about what Canada’s clean energy “nerds” are up to? Visit http://generationenergy.ca for more information.  #GenEnergy

Student research assistants Nicolas Piette-Lauziere and Zoik Brault are in the field at the edge of Cape Breton Highlands National Park. They are proudly displaying their #GSC175 commemorative t-shirts! 
Over the last month, Nicolas and Zoik have been mapping a fault zone on Cape Breton Island that separates rocks with different geological histories on either side. By studying the fault zone in the field, and collecting samples to study in the lab, Nicolas hopes to discover when and why it formed, and how it may have created a pathway for magma deep in the Earth’s crust to rise and form granite.

The zero-emission hydrogen fuel cell Mirai produces only water as the byproduct of it’s power generation.  Hydrogen vehicles can travel as far as gas vehicles on equivalent tank of gas and are just as quick to refuel!  This car is one of three currently available for purchase, and investments into hydrogen fueling stations are being made by federal and provincial governments.

#ICYMI – Canadian #CleanTech innovation was showcased during the #GenEnergy forum. This battery-powered Eco-Marathon car was designed by @umecomotion, a group of engineering students at the University of Manitoba. The Eco-Marathon competition challenges students to design and build cars to see which vehicle can travel the farthest distance on a single litre of fuel. The car had to do 10 laps on a one-kilometre circuit and was judged on its kilometres per kilowatt hours. The team placed 14th out of 27 in the battery-electric prototype category in Detroit in April 2017.
Here’s what the National Post said about the #GenEnergy forum:

Here are two #CleanTech innovations that were showcased at the #GenEnergy forum!

The EV Garage is an interactive display designed to help Canadians explore and better understand electric vehicles and solar energy production for vehicles and buildings.

The Chevy Volt is a hybrid plug-in electric vehicle. The car uses the battery power until the battery is empty, at which point gas can be used. The Volt has regenerative braking to help charge the battery.
Here’s what Fatih Birol said about the Global Energy Outlook at the #GenEnergy forum

Here’s another #CleanTech innovation that was featured at the #GenEnergy forum.

This is the EnCurrent hydrokinetic turbine.
This turbine is ideal for power generation in remote communities. A 25kW version of this turbine is being installed in the Sagkeeng First Nation Community on the Winnipeg River; 25kW could charge a medium-sized home or business. This installation also gives NRCan a chance to monitor the performance of the turbine. These turbines have also been installed elsewhere in Canada, the U.S. and India.

Did you know that methane accounts for roughly 15% of Canada’s total GHG emissions, with oil and gas production being the largest producer?
That’s why Canada is investing $5.3 million in clean tech projects to reduce methane emissions from oil and gas production.

International collaboration at its best! Canada’s Extended Continental Shelf Program is advancing scientific research. 
In the Atlantic Ocean, Canada collaborated with its neighbours in their scientific work, including with Denmark in the Labrador Sea and with the United States off the Scotian Shelf southwest of Nova Scotia. 
In the Arctic Ocean, Canada collaborated on joint surveys with Denmark and the United States, and had a cooperation with Russia. 
#ArcticScience
